page.title: 01Trawsfynydd
page.content: Trawsfynydd is a small village of about 600 inhabitants serving a large agricultural community. This is an area of upland farming with extensive tracts of moorland. The lowest point being at 750 feet. Very little change has taken place in the last century. The architecture of the area remaining predominantly local stone although newer buildings are rendered in order to comply with National Park regulations. Some afforestation has taken place in areas of very marginal land. The major source of employment being sheep farming apart from the local power station. Tourism has not figured strongly in this area yet.
